risk_levels.low: Clearly defined in IRS guidance with explicit rules
risk_levels.medium: IRS has provided partial guidance; some interpretation required
risk_levels.high: Gray area - IRS has not directly commented; legal uncertainty exists

changelog.changes: Added updated field, risk_level field, specific source citations

chunks.title: IRS Classification of Cryptocurrency
chunks.content: The IRS treats cryptocurrency as PROPERTY, not currency. This was established in IRS Notice 2014-21 and remains true today. This means general tax rules for property transactions (like stocks or real estate) apply to crypto. When you dispose of cryptocurrency (selling, trading, spending), it results in a capital gain or loss. If you receive crypto as payment for work, it's treated as ordinary income at fair market value.
chunks.source: IRS Notice 2014-21, Section 4, Q&A-1
chunks.simple_answer: Crypto is treated like property (similar to stocks). When you sell or trade it, you pay capital gains tax. When you earn it, you pay income tax.

chunks.title: IRS Definition of Digital Asset
chunks.content: A digital asset is defined as 'any digital representation of value that is recorded on a cryptographically secured distributed ledger or any similar technology.' This includes: cryptocurrencies (Bitcoin, Ethereum), stablecoins (USDT, USDC), and NFTs (non-fungible tokens). This definition comes from the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (2021) and is used on Form 1040.
chunks.source: Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act Section 80603; IRS Form 1040 Instructions (2023)
chunks.simple_answer: Digital asset = anything on a blockchain with value. Includes Bitcoin, Ethereum, stablecoins like USDT, and NFTs.

chunks.title: Selling Crypto for Fiat (USD)
chunks.content: Selling cryptocurrency for fiat currency (USD) is a TAXABLE EVENT. It triggers capital gain or loss. You must calculate the difference between the USD value you receive and your cost basis (what you originally paid).
chunks.source: IRS Notice 2014-21, Q&A-6; IRS FAQ on Virtual Currency Q4
chunks.simple_answer: Yes, selling crypto for dollars is taxable. Your tax = (what you sold for) minus (what you paid). Profit = capital gain. Loss = capital loss.
chunks.example: Bought 1 BTC for $30,000. Sold for $50,000. Capital gain = $20,000.

chunks.title: Trading Crypto for Crypto (Swaps)
chunks.content: Trading one cryptocurrency for another is a TAXABLE EVENT. This includes swapping on DEXs like Uniswap. It's treated as selling one asset for market value and buying another. You must calculate capital gain or loss on the crypto you gave up. This applies even when converting to stablecoins (USDT, USDC, DAI).
chunks.source: IRS Notice 2014-21, Q&A-6; IRS FAQ on Virtual Currency Q5
chunks.simple_answer: Yes, swapping crypto is taxable. Example: Trading ETH for USDC = you 'sold' your ETH. Calculate gain/loss on the ETH you gave up.
chunks.example: Bought 1 ETH for $1,000. Swapped it for 2,000 USDC when ETH = $2,000. Capital gain = $1,000.

chunks.title: Spending Crypto on Goods/Services
chunks.content: Using cryptocurrency to pay for goods or services is a TAXABLE EVENT. You are deemed to have 'sold' the crypto at market value. You must calculate capital gain or loss (market value minus your cost basis).
chunks.source: IRS Notice 2014-21, Q&A-6
chunks.simple_answer: Yes, spending crypto is taxable. If you buy a $5,000 item with Bitcoin you bought for $2,000, you have a $3,000 capital gain.
chunks.example: Bought 0.1 BTC for $3,000. Used it to buy a laptop when 0.1 BTC = $4,000. Capital gain = $1,000.

chunks.title: Receiving Crypto as Payment for Work
chunks.content: Receiving cryptocurrency as payment for work or services is TAXABLE as ordinary income. The amount is the fair market value (FMV) of the crypto when you received it. This becomes your cost basis for future sales. Reported like regular wages. If self-employed, subject to self-employment tax.
chunks.source: IRS Notice 2014-21, Q&A-8, Q&A-9; IRS FAQ Q12
chunks.simple_answer: Getting paid in crypto = regular income. If you receive $5,000 worth of ETH for freelance work, that's $5,000 of taxable income. Your cost basis in that ETH is $5,000.
chunks.example: Received 1 ETH worth $2,000 for consulting work. Report $2,000 as income. Cost basis = $2,000.

question_triggers: do I pay tax on mining
chunks.title: Mining Rewards Taxation
chunks.content: Cryptocurrency earned from mining is ORDINARY INCOME at the fair market value when you receive the coins. If mining as a business (trade or business), it may also be subject to self-employment tax (15.3%), but you can deduct expenses (equipment, electricity, depreciation). If mining as a hobby, report as 'other income' but cannot deduct expenses. The mined coins' cost basis is their value when obtained.
chunks.source: IRS Notice 2014-21, Q&A-8; IRS FAQ Q8
chunks.simple_answer: Mining rewards = income when you receive them. If you mine $1,000 worth of BTC, that's $1,000 income. Later selling it creates another tax event (capital gain/loss from that $1,000 basis).
chunks.example: Mined 0.01 BTC worth $500. Report $500 as income. Later sell for $800. Capital gain = $300.

question_triggers: do I pay tax on staking
chunks.title: Staking Rewards Taxation
chunks.content: Staking rewards are ORDINARY INCOME when you gain 'dominion and control' over them. This means when you can transfer, sell, or dispose of the tokens. Per IRS Revenue Ruling 2023-14: if rewards are locked, you don't owe tax until they become unlocked/accessible. The fair market value at that time is your taxable income and becomes your cost basis. Same treatment applies whether you stake directly or through an exchange.
chunks.source: IRS Revenue Ruling 2023-14
chunks.simple_answer: Staking rewards = income when you can access them. If you earn 0.1 ETH from staking worth $200, that's $200 income when you can withdraw it. If there's a lock-up period, tax applies when lock-up ends.
chunks.example: Staked ETH, earned 0.2 ETH rewards. Lock-up ended April 15 when 0.2 ETH = $400. Report $400 income on April 15. Cost basis = $400.
chunks.note: Rev. Rul. 2023-14 definitively settled staking taxation after years of uncertainty

chunks.title: Staking Rewards - Timing of Taxation
chunks.content: You include staking rewards in gross income when you RECEIVE them and can CONTROL them. If rewards are initially locked (some protocols require lock-up), you don't have taxable income until they become unlocked/accessible. 'Dominion and control' means you can transfer, sell, or dispose of the coins. This is the key test for timing.
chunks.source: IRS Revenue Ruling 2023-14
chunks.simple_answer: Tax kicks in when you can actually use your staking rewards. Locked rewards = no tax yet. Once unlocked = taxable at that day's value.

chunks.title: Buying Crypto with Fiat
chunks.content: Simply purchasing cryptocurrency with dollars (or any fiat) is NOT a taxable event. You are just establishing your cost basis (what you paid). No gain or loss is realized until you dispose of the crypto. This includes buying through exchanges, ATMs, or peer-to-peer.
chunks.source: IRS FAQ on Virtual Currency Q5 (clarification); IRS Form 1040 Instructions (2023)
chunks.simple_answer: No tax when you buy crypto with dollars. You're just establishing what you paid (cost basis). Tax only happens when you sell, trade, or spend it.

chunks.title: Transferring Crypto Between Your Own Wallets
chunks.content: Moving your coins from one exchange to another, or from an exchange to your personal wallet (or vice versa), is NOT a taxable event. You still own the asset - it's just a transfer. Keep records to track original cost basis and acquisition date. Note: Moving to Layer 2 or wrapping may have different treatment (see wrapping section).
chunks.source: IRS FAQ on Virtual Currency; IRS Form 1040 Instructions (2023)
chunks.simple_answer: No tax for moving crypto between your own wallets. Coinbase to Ledger? Not taxable. Just keep records of original purchase info.

question_triggers: do I pay tax just for holding
chunks.title: Holding Cryptocurrency (HODL)
chunks.content: If you simply hold (HODL) your crypto and do nothing with it, there is NO taxable event. You can watch it go up or down with no tax until you actually sell or exchange it. There is no 'unrealized capital gains tax' at the federal level - you're only taxed when gains are realized through a disposition.
chunks.source: IRS General Tax Principles; IRC Section 1001 (realization requirement)
chunks.simple_answer: Just holding = no tax. Your Bitcoin went from $30k to $60k but you didn't sell? No tax yet. Tax only when you sell.

chunks.title: Gifting Cryptocurrency
chunks.content: Making a gift of crypto is NOT immediately taxable for the giver. If gift is below annual exclusion ($18,000 per recipient in 2024, $19,000 in 2025), no gift tax return needed. Above that may require Form 709 but usually no tax due (lifetime exclusion $13.61M in 2024, $13.99M in 2025). Recipient doesn't owe income tax on receiving it. When recipient sells, they use the giver's original cost basis (carryover basis).
chunks.source: IRC Section 102 (gifts excluded from income); IRC Section 2503 (annual exclusion); IRS Publication 559
chunks.simple_answer: Gifting crypto = not taxable for you. Up to $18,000/person (2024) or $19,000 (2025) without paperwork. The recipient inherits your cost basis when they sell.
chunks.example: You gift 1 ETH (bought at $1,000) to your child. No tax for you. Child later sells for $3,000. Child pays tax on $2,000 gain.

chunks.title: Short-Term Capital Gains
chunks.content: If you held crypto 1 YEAR OR LESS before selling, any gain is SHORT-TERM and taxed at ordinary income tax rates (same rates as your salary). For 2024, rates are: 10%, 12%, 22%, 24%, 32%, 35%, and 37% depending on total taxable income. Short-term gains are just added to your regular income.
chunks.source: IRC Section 1222 (short-term defined); IRC Section 1 (tax rates)
chunks.simple_answer: Held less than 1 year = short-term = taxed like regular income. If you're in the 24% tax bracket, your crypto gains are taxed at 24%.

chunks.title: Long-Term Capital Gains
chunks.content: If you held crypto MORE THAN 1 YEAR before selling, you qualify for long-term capital gains tax rates: 0%, 15%, or 20% depending on income. These rates are generally much more favorable than short-term (ordinary income) rates. High earners may also owe 3.8% NIIT on top.
chunks.source: IRC Section 1(h) (capital gains rates); IRC Section 1222
chunks.simple_answer: Held more than 1 year = long-term = lower tax rates (0%, 15%, or 20%). If your income is under ~$47k (single), you might pay 0% on crypto gains!

chunks.title: NFT Collectibles Tax Rate
chunks.content: NFTs representing collectibles (art, etc.) may be taxed at a higher rate. Long-term gains on collectibles have a maximum 28% tax rate (instead of 20%). Many NFTs like digital artwork likely fall under this category. Short-term gains on NFTs are still taxed at ordinary income rates. IRS requested comments in Notice 2023-27 on how to determine if an NFT is a collectible.
chunks.source: IRC Section 408(m)(2) (collectibles defined); IRS Notice 2023-27
chunks.simple_answer: NFTs (especially art) might be taxed as 'collectibles' with max 28% long-term rate instead of 20%. Short-term is still regular income tax rates.
chunks.note: IRS Notice 2023-27 requested comments but hasn't issued final guidance on NFT collectible classification

chunks.title: Net Investment Income Tax (NIIT)
chunks.content: High-income taxpayers may owe an additional 3.8% Net Investment Income Tax (NIIT) on investment income including crypto gains. Applies if modified adjusted gross income exceeds $200,000 (single) or $250,000 (married filing jointly). This means effective long-term rates could be 18.8% or 23.8%, and short-term up to 40.8%.
chunks.source: IRC Section 1411; IRS Form 8960
chunks.simple_answer: Make over $200k (single) or $250k (married)? Add 3.8% extra tax on your crypto gains. So 15% long-term becomes 18.8%.

chunks.title: Airdrop Taxation
chunks.content: If you receive an airdropped token, it is ORDINARY INCOME when you have control of it, equal to its fair market value. This is true even if you didn't ask for it. Your cost basis in airdropped tokens equals the income amount recognized (FMV at receipt). Taxable in the year you gain dominion and control.
chunks.source: IRS Revenue Ruling 2019-24; IRS FAQ Q24, Q25
chunks.simple_answer: Airdrops = income when you receive them. Got 100 free tokens worth $500? That's $500 income. Your cost basis is $500.
chunks.example: Received 400 UNI airdrop worth $1,200. Report $1,200 as income. Later sold for $4,000. Capital gain = $2,800.

chunks.title: Scam or Unwanted Airdrop Tokens
chunks.content: If tokens appear in your wallet that are spam or you can't actually sell/transfer them, you may not have income because you have no 'dominion and control' (and potentially no value). The IRS hasn't explicitly addressed this. Document the situation with screenshots showing the token is untradeable. If later it becomes legitimate and you use it, that may become taxable then.
chunks.source: Tax professional interpretation based on dominion and control principles from Rev. Rul. 2019-24
chunks.simple_answer: Random scam tokens you can't sell? Probably not taxable since you can't control them. Keep screenshots as proof they're worthless/untradeable.
chunks.note: No explicit IRS guidance on scam/spam tokens; interpretation based on general principles

chunks.title: Hard Fork - No New Coins Received
chunks.content: If your crypto undergoes a hard fork but you do NOT receive any new cryptocurrency, there is NO taxable event. You're simply holding the same coins on an updated network. Example: Ethereum merge (ETH 1.0 to 2.0) didn't create new coins, so not taxable.
chunks.source: IRS Revenue Ruling 2019-24, Situation 1
chunks.simple_answer: Fork happened but you didn't get any new coins? No tax. Nothing changed for you.

chunks.title: Hard Fork - New Coins Received
chunks.content: If a hard fork results in you receiving new cryptocurrency (via airdrop), you have ORDINARY INCOME when you gain 'dominion and control' over the new tokens. The fair market value at that time is your taxable income and becomes your cost basis. Example: Bitcoin Cash fork gave BTC holders new BCH - that was taxable income.
chunks.source: IRS Revenue Ruling 2019-24, Situation 2
chunks.simple_answer: Fork gave you new coins? That's income when you can access them. Got 1 BCH worth $300? Report $300 as income.
chunks.example: Held 2 BTC during fork. Received 2 BCH worth $600 total. Report $600 income. Cost basis in BCH = $600.

chunks.title: Hard Fork - Dominion and Control
chunks.content: You don't have taxable income from a fork until you can actually ACCESS the new coins. If your exchange doesn't support the new token, you have no income until they do (or you claim it elsewhere). If an exchange never supports it and you never claim it, you never received it = no income. The key test is whether you can 'transfer, sell, exchange, or otherwise dispose of' the cryptocurrency.
chunks.source: IRS Revenue Ruling 2019-24; IRS FAQ Q24
chunks.simple_answer: Can't actually access the forked coins? No tax yet. Exchange doesn't support them? Wait until they do (or you claim elsewhere). That's when tax kicks in.

chunks.title: DeFi Token Swaps (DEX Trades)
chunks.content: Trading on a DEX (Uniswap, SushiSwap, PancakeSwap, etc.) is treated the same as centralized exchanges for tax purposes. Swapping one token for another = TAXABLE EVENT. Calculate capital gain/loss on the token you gave up. The new token's cost basis = value used in the trade. Gas fees are part of the transaction cost.
chunks.source: IRS Notice 2014-21 (applied to DeFi by analogy); No specific DeFi guidance issued
chunks.simple_answer: Swapping on Uniswap is just as taxable as trading on Coinbase. ETH → DAI = you 'sold' your ETH.
chunks.example: Swapped 0.5 ETH (basis $800, now worth $1,000) for AAVE. Capital gain = $200. AAVE cost basis = $1,000.
chunks.note: While no specific DeFi guidance exists, swaps clearly fall under existing property exchange rules

chunks.title: Entering Liquidity Pools
chunks.content: When you deposit assets into a liquidity pool and receive LP tokens, the CONSERVATIVE approach (recommended) treats this as a taxable trade: you're exchanging your tokens for a new asset (LP token). Capital gains may be triggered if your deposited tokens appreciated since you bought them. Some argue it's just a 'deposit' but since you receive a new tradable token, most tax professionals treat it as a swap.
chunks.source: Tax professional consensus; No explicit IRS guidance on LP tokens
chunks.simple_answer: Adding liquidity is likely taxable. You're swapping your tokens for LP tokens. If your ETH gained value since you bought it, you may owe tax when depositing.
chunks.example: Deposit 1 ETH (bought $1,500, now $1,800) + 2,000 USDC into pool, get LP tokens. Gain on ETH = $300.
chunks.note: No explicit IRS guidance on LP tokens. Conservative treatment recommended.

chunks.title: Liquidity Pool Rewards
chunks.content: Reward tokens earned from liquidity pools (like CRV from Curve, CAKE from PancakeSwap, UNI from Uniswap) are ORDINARY INCOME when received at fair market value. This is similar to staking or airdrops. Those tokens then have a cost basis equal to the income recognized.
chunks.source: Tax professional interpretation; analogous to staking/mining income treatment
chunks.simple_answer: Earning reward tokens (CRV, UNI, etc.) from LPs = income at the value when received.
chunks.example: Earned 5 CRV worth $10 each from Curve pool. Report $50 as income. CRV cost basis = $50 total.
chunks.note: Treatment by analogy to staking rewards; no specific IRS guidance on LP rewards

chunks.title: Exiting Liquidity Pools
chunks.content: When you remove liquidity, you 'burn' LP tokens and receive underlying assets. This is another TAXABLE EVENT - you may have gain or loss on the LP tokens. The assets you receive start fresh with cost basis equal to their value at withdrawal. Impermanent loss is factored into the overall gain/loss calculation on the LP tokens.
chunks.source: Tax professional consensus; No explicit IRS guidance
chunks.simple_answer: Removing liquidity = another taxable event. Compare what your LP tokens are worth now vs. your basis in them.
chunks.example: LP tokens basis = $3,800. Withdraw assets worth $4,000. Capital gain = $200.
chunks.note: No explicit IRS guidance. Impermanent loss treatment is particularly unclear.

chunks.title: DeFi Lending and Interest
chunks.content: Interest/yield earned from lending crypto (Compound, Aave, etc.) is ORDINARY INCOME when received at fair market value. Whether paid in kind (more crypto) or another token, it's taxable. Some protocols give tokens (cTokens, aTokens) that increase in value - gains may be realized when you swap back. IRS Notice 2024-57 exempted certain DeFi lending from broker reporting, but transactions are still taxable.
chunks.source: IRS general income principles; Notice 2024-57 (broker reporting exemption)
chunks.simple_answer: Earning interest on DeFi = income. Deposited DAI and earned more DAI? That extra DAI is taxable income.
chunks.example: Lent 1,000 USDC, earned 50 USDC interest over the year. Report $50 as income.
chunks.note: Notice 2024-57 exempted from broker reporting but not from taxation

chunks.title: DeFi Borrowing
chunks.content: Borrowing crypto or stablecoins is NOT a taxable event. Loans are not income because you must repay. This is a key tax advantage: you can borrow against appreciated crypto without triggering a sale. HOWEVER, if your collateral is LIQUIDATED, that IS a taxable event (treated as a forced sale). Interest paid on loans may be deductible if used for investment purposes.
chunks.source: IRS general loan principles; IRC Section 163 (interest deduction)
chunks.simple_answer: Taking a crypto loan = not taxable. But if your collateral gets liquidated, that's treated as a sale with potential capital gains.
chunks.example: Deposited 1 BTC (basis $10k) as collateral. Got liquidated at $15k. Capital gain = $5k even though you didn't choose to sell.

chunks.title: Wrapped Tokens and Bridging
chunks.content: Wrapping a token (ETH to WETH) or bridging to another chain COULD be considered a taxable event (swapping one asset for another). The IRS hasn't explicitly ruled. Conservative view: it might be taxable since you receive a different token. Common practice: many don't treat 1:1 wraps as taxable if value is identical. IRS delayed broker reporting for wrapping (Notice 2024-57), suggesting they're still developing guidance.
chunks.source: IRS Notice 2024-57 (exempted from broker reporting); No direct IRS guidance on wrapping
chunks.simple_answer: Wrapping ETH to WETH? Gray area. Many don't report it since value is the same, but technically it could be taxable. Be cautious near year-end.
chunks.note: IRS has not ruled directly on wrapping. Notice 2024-57 exemption from broker reporting suggests ongoing consideration.

chunks.title: Buying an NFT with Crypto
chunks.content: Purchasing an NFT with cryptocurrency triggers a TAXABLE EVENT on the crypto you spend. You're effectively 'selling' your crypto for the NFT. Calculate gain/loss on the crypto used. Your cost basis in the NFT = the crypto's value at purchase (plus gas fees).
chunks.source: IRS Notice 2014-21 (property rules); IRS FAQ on Virtual Currency
chunks.simple_answer: Buying an NFT with ETH = you 'sold' your ETH. If your ETH gained value, you owe tax on that gain.
chunks.example: Used 0.1 BTC (basis $3,000, now worth $4,000) to buy NFT. Capital gain = $1,000. NFT cost basis = $4,000.

chunks.title: Selling an NFT
chunks.content: Selling or disposing of an NFT is a TAXABLE EVENT triggering capital gain or loss. Gain/loss = sale price (USD) minus your cost basis in the NFT. If sold for crypto, convert to USD value on that day. May be subject to collectibles rate (28% max) if held long-term.
chunks.source: IRS property rules; IRS Notice 2023-27 (collectibles)
chunks.simple_answer: Selling an NFT = capital gains tax. Profit = what you sold for minus what you paid.
chunks.example: Bought NFT for 0.5 ETH ($1,000). Sold for 1 ETH ($2,500). Capital gain = $1,500.

chunks.title: Creating and Selling NFTs (as Creator)
chunks.content: If you mint and sell your own NFT (artwork, content), proceeds are ORDINARY INCOME, not capital gain. You created it (essentially zero basis) and sold it as inventory/art. Could be self-employment income if you regularly create art for sale, subject to self-employment tax. Royalties from resales are also ordinary income.
chunks.source: IRS self-employment rules; IRC Section 1221 (capital asset exclusions)
chunks.simple_answer: Created and sold your own NFT? That's regular income (like selling art), not capital gains. No special lower tax rate.

chunks.title: Gas Fees for NFTs
chunks.content: Gas fees paid to ACQUIRE an NFT are added to your cost basis (reduces future gain). Gas fees paid when SELLING reduce your proceeds. For creators, minting costs (gas, platform fees) are business expenses. Failed transaction fees are generally not deductible (considered sunk cost with no clear guidance).
chunks.source: IRS general expense principles; No specific crypto gas fee guidance
chunks.simple_answer: Gas to buy NFT? Add to your cost basis (lowers future gain). Gas to sell? Reduces your sale proceeds. Failed transaction gas? Usually just lost money, not deductible.

chunks.title: Wash Sale Rule - Current Status
chunks.content: The wash sale rule currently does NOT apply to cryptocurrency. Crypto is treated as property, not a 'security' under IRC §1091. This means you CAN sell crypto at a loss, immediately buy it back, and still claim the loss. This enables tax-loss harvesting without the 30-day waiting period required for stocks.
chunks.source: IRC Section 1091 (wash sales); IRS Notice 2014-21 (crypto as property, not security)
chunks.simple_answer: Currently, you CAN sell crypto at a loss and buy it right back. The wash sale rule doesn't apply to crypto (yet). This is a legal tax advantage.
chunks.example: BTC dropped from $60k to $30k. Sell at $30k loss, immediately rebuy. Claim the $30k loss on taxes while keeping your BTC position.
chunks.note: As of Dec 2024, wash sale does not apply to crypto. This may change with future legislation.

chunks.title: Wash Sale Caution and Economic Substance
chunks.content: Although legal, the IRS could theoretically invoke the 'economic substance doctrine' if transactions have no purpose other than tax avoidance. To be safer: allow a short delay before rebuying (a few days), or swap into a different (but similar) crypto temporarily. This shows some economic purpose beyond just taxes.
chunks.source: IRC Section 7701(o) (economic substance doctrine); Tax professional guidance
chunks.simple_answer: It's legal, but be smart. Some advisors suggest waiting a few days or swapping to a similar coin (not identical) before buying back. Shows you had some investment reason, not just tax games.

chunks.title: Wash Sale - Potential Future Changes
chunks.content: Multiple proposals have tried to extend wash sale rules to crypto: Build Back Better Act (2021), Biden FY2024/2025 budgets. None have passed yet as of December 2024. If enacted, you'd need to wait 30 days before rebuying the same crypto to claim a loss. Stay informed about new tax laws.
chunks.source: Build Back Better Act (H.R. 5376); Biden FY2025 Budget Proposal
chunks.simple_answer: Lawmakers keep trying to close this 'loophole.' It hasn't passed yet, but could in the future. Enjoy tax-loss harvesting while you can, but watch for law changes.
chunks.note: Status as of Dec 2024: No legislation passed. Proposals ongoing.

chunks.title: Form 1040 Digital Asset Question
chunks.content: Form 1040 asks: 'At any time during the year, did you: (a) receive (as a reward, award, or payment); or (b) sell, exchange, gift, or otherwise dispose of any digital asset?' Answer YES if you: sold, traded, spent, received as payment, received staking/mining rewards, received airdrops, or gifted crypto. Answer NO only if you: just held, only bought with fiat, or only transferred between your own wallets.
chunks.source: IRS Form 1040 (2023, 2024); IRS FAQ on Virtual Currency
chunks.simple_answer: The IRS asks everyone about crypto. Check 'Yes' if you did anything except buy or hold. Check 'No' only if you just bought and held (no selling, no trading, no earning).

chunks.title: Form 8949 - Reporting Sales
chunks.content: Use Form 8949 for detailed capital transactions. List each sale/trade: description (e.g., '0.5 BTC'), date acquired, date sold, proceeds, cost basis, and gain/loss. Categorize as short-term (Part I) or long-term (Part II). Totals flow to Schedule D. If many transactions, can attach summary and keep detailed records.
chunks.source: IRS Form 8949 Instructions
chunks.simple_answer: Form 8949 = list all your crypto trades. Date bought, date sold, what you paid, what you got, gain or loss. Schedule D summarizes the totals.

chunks.title: Form 1099-DA (New for 2025)
chunks.content: Starting 2025, exchanges must issue Form 1099-DA reporting your crypto sales to you and the IRS. For 2025: reports gross proceeds. For 2026+: also includes cost basis for assets acquired on that platform after Jan 1, 2026. DeFi/non-custodial platforms currently exempt from broker reporting (per IRS final regs and congressional action in early 2025). FIFO becomes default method for brokers.
chunks.source: IRS Final Regulations TD 9989 (July 2024); IRC Section 6045 (as amended)
chunks.simple_answer: Starting 2025, exchanges like Coinbase will send you (and the IRS) a 1099-DA showing your sales. By 2026, they'll include cost basis too. DeFi trades won't be reported (but still taxable).
chunks.note: DeFi broker rule was overturned by Congress in early 2025

chunks.title: Cost Basis Methods
chunks.content: IRS allows: Specific Identification (you choose which coins to sell - includes FIFO, LIFO, HIFO strategies) or FIFO default (first coins bought = first sold). HIFO (Highest In, First Out) minimizes gains by selling highest-cost coins first. Through 2025, you have flexibility to choose. Starting 2026, brokers default to FIFO unless you give specific instructions before the sale.
chunks.source: IRS Regulations; Revenue Procedure 2024-28
chunks.simple_answer: FIFO = sell oldest coins first. HIFO = sell most expensive coins first (usually best for taxes). You can choose through 2025. After that, exchanges default to FIFO.

chunks.title: Cost Basis Changes in 2026
chunks.content: Starting 2026, brokers must use FIFO as default for reporting. You cannot retroactively change which lots were sold after the fact. If you want to use HIFO or specific ID, you must tell your exchange or arrange transfers to make it clear BEFORE the sale. Revenue Procedure 2024-28 provides transition rules for allocating basis in existing holdings as of Jan 1, 2025.
chunks.source: IRS Final Regulations TD 9989; Revenue Procedure 2024-28
chunks.simple_answer: After 2025, FIFO is the default and you can't change it after the fact. Want to use HIFO? Tell your exchange before selling, or manage your coins in separate wallets.

chunks.title: Tax-Loss Harvesting
chunks.content: If crypto investments are down, sell them to realize capital losses. Losses offset gains dollar-for-dollar. Up to $3,000 of net losses can reduce ordinary income per year. Excess carries forward indefinitely. Because wash sale doesn't apply to crypto (yet), you can rebuy immediately. Best done before December 31 to count for current tax year.
chunks.source: IRC Section 1211 (capital loss limitation); IRC Section 1212 (carryover)
chunks.simple_answer: Lost money on some coins? Sell them to 'harvest' the loss. Use it to offset gains. Up to $3k can offset regular income too. You can even rebuy the same coin right away (for now).
chunks.example: Have $10k in crypto gains. Also holding a coin down $5k. Sell the loser. Now you only pay tax on $5k of gains.

chunks.title: Hold for Long-Term Rates
chunks.content: Hold crypto more than 1 year before selling to qualify for long-term capital gains rates (0%, 15%, or 20%) instead of ordinary income rates (up to 37%). For lower/middle income, this could mean 0% tax on gains. The holding period starts the day after acquisition.
chunks.source: IRC Section 1222; IRC Section 1(h)
chunks.simple_answer: Patience pays. Hold over 1 year = potentially 0% or 15% tax instead of up to 37%. Make under ~$47k (single)? You'll pay 0%. Under ~$94k (married)? Also 0%.

chunks.title: Charitable Donations of Crypto
chunks.content: Donating crypto directly to a qualified 501(c)(3) charity: you can deduct the full fair market value (if held >1 year) and pay NO capital gains tax on the appreciation. Double benefit. Limits: deduction capped at 30% of AGI (excess carries forward 5 years). Must itemize deductions. Get a receipt; donations over $5,000 need qualified appraisal.
chunks.source: IRC Section 170 (charitable contributions); IRS Publication 526
chunks.simple_answer: Donate appreciated crypto to charity = deduct full value + avoid capital gains tax. Best of both worlds.
chunks.example: Have 2 BTC bought for $10k, now worth $60k. Donate directly to charity. Get $60k deduction. Pay $0 capital gains tax.

chunks.title: Key Tax Deadlines
chunks.content: December 31: End of tax year. Last day for tax-loss harvesting for current year. April 15: File return (or extension) and PAY taxes due for prior year. October 15: Extended filing deadline (if extension filed). Quarterly estimated taxes: April 15, June 15, September 15, January 15.
chunks.source: IRC Section 6072 (filing dates); IRC Section 6654 (estimated tax)
chunks.simple_answer: Dec 31 = last day to harvest losses for the year. April 15 = file and pay (or file extension, but still pay). October 15 = extended deadline.

chunks.title: Upcoming Regulatory Changes
chunks.content: January 1, 2025: Brokers start tracking/reporting sales (1099-DA for gross proceeds). January 2026: You receive 1099-DA forms for 2025 trades. January 1, 2026: Brokers include cost basis in reporting; FIFO becomes default for broker reporting. Watch for potential wash sale legislation - none passed as of Dec 2024.
chunks.source: IRS Final Regulations TD 9989; Revenue Procedure 2024-28
chunks.simple_answer: 2025: Exchanges report your sales to IRS. 2026: They report your cost basis too, and FIFO is the default. Big changes coming - get your records in order now.

question_triggers: what if I don't report crypto
chunks.title: Penalties for Non-Compliance
chunks.content: Failure to file: 5% of unpaid tax per month, up to 25%. Failure to pay: 0.5% per month, up to 25%. Accuracy penalty: 20% of underpayment if due to negligence or substantial understatement. Fraud penalty: 75% of underpayment. Criminal charges possible for willful evasion (up to $250k fine, prison). Always file, even if you can't pay - failure to file penalty is worse.
chunks.source: IRC Section 6651 (failure to file/pay); IRC Section 6662 (accuracy); IRC Section 6663 (fraud)
chunks.simple_answer: Not filing = 5%/month penalty (up to 25%). Not paying = 0.5%/month. Intentional fraud = 75% penalty + possible criminal charges. Always file - you can set up payment plans.

chunks.title: IRS Enforcement Efforts
chunks.content: IRS has issued John Doe summonses to major exchanges (Coinbase, Kraken, Circle) for customer data. They use blockchain analytics (Chainalysis, CipherTrace) to trace transactions. Sent warning letters to thousands of suspected non-filers. In 2024, first criminal case brought specifically for crypto tax evasion. Starting 2025, exchanges must report via 1099-DA. The IRS is serious about crypto compliance.
chunks.source: IRS press releases; DOJ announcements; IR-2019-167
chunks.simple_answer: The IRS knows more than you think. They get data from exchanges, trace blockchain transactions, and are prosecuting crypto tax evaders. Don't assume you can hide.

chunks.title: FAQ: Do I Report If I Only Had Losses?
chunks.content: YES. You must report all sales, regardless of profit or loss. Reporting losses is BENEFICIAL - they offset other income (up to $3k/year) and carry forward indefinitely. Don't skip reporting losses - they help reduce your taxes now and in future years.
chunks.source: IRC Section 1211; IRS Form 8949 Instructions
chunks.simple_answer: Yes! Report losses. They reduce your taxes. Up to $3k can offset your salary income. The rest carries forward to future years.

chunks.title: FAQ: Is Converting to Stablecoin Taxable?
chunks.content: YES. Swapping crypto for a stablecoin (USDT, USDC, DAI) is a taxable event. You're 'selling' your crypto for the stablecoin. Calculate gain/loss on the crypto you gave up. The stablecoin is just another cryptocurrency for tax purposes - its stable value doesn't change this.
chunks.source: IRS Notice 2014-21; IRS FAQ on Virtual Currency
chunks.simple_answer: Yes, converting BTC to USDC is taxable. You 'sold' your BTC. If it gained value, you owe tax. The fact that USDC is stable to $1 doesn't change this.

chunks.title: FAQ: Foreign Exchanges and DeFi
chunks.content: YES, you owe tax on worldwide income regardless of where the exchange is located or if it's DeFi with no KYC. The IRS uses blockchain analytics to trace transactions. They've issued summonses to foreign affiliates. May also need to file FBAR (FinCEN 114) if foreign account value exceeded $10,000 at any point. Don't assume anonymity protects you.
chunks.source: IRC Section 61 (worldwide income); 31 USC 5314 (FBAR)
chunks.simple_answer: Doesn't matter if it's a foreign exchange or anonymous DeFi - you owe US taxes on all gains. The IRS can trace blockchain transactions. Report everything.

chunks.title: FAQ: Lost Access to Crypto
chunks.content: Simply losing your private key or sending to wrong address is generally NOT deductible. The IRS requires an 'identifiable event' that fixes the loss with certainty. Losing access isn't a completed transaction. For theft/hacks: personal theft losses haven't been deductible since 2018 TCJA. Exchange bankruptcy: may eventually allow deduction when certain you won't recover, but guidance is limited.
chunks.source: IRC Section 165 (losses); TCJA 2017 (suspended personal casualty losses)
chunks.simple_answer: Lost your keys? Unfortunately, probably not tax-deductible. It's not a 'completed transaction' in IRS eyes. Hacked? Also not deductible for individuals since 2018. Exchange collapse? Maybe eventually, but complicated.
chunks.note: No clear IRS guidance on lost access; exchange bankruptcy treatment developing

chunks.title: FAQ: Like-Kind Exchange (1031)
chunks.content: NO, like-kind exchange treatment is NOT available for crypto. Since 2018, IRC Section 1031 is restricted to real estate only. Every crypto-to-crypto trade is fully taxable in the year it happens. You cannot defer gains by reinvesting into other crypto. This was sometimes claimed pre-2018 but was always aggressive and is now definitively unavailable.
chunks.source: IRC Section 1031 (as amended by TCJA 2017)
chunks.simple_answer: No, you can't use 1031 exchanges for crypto. That's only for real estate now. Trading BTC for ETH is taxable - no deferrals allowed.
